title: 110_s1451
content: The Act titled "Quality Reform Expansion and Savings Act of 2007" is cited as the short title. The findings and purpose of the Act are outlined in section 2. The United States health care system needs urgent reform to improve care quality, optimize investments, and prevent illness. Payment systems often hinder investment in prevention and quality improvement. Tailored reforms can lower costs and enhance care quality. Despite the need for reform, there is a lack of national effort to implement necessary changes. Many state and local initiatives are already in progress. The Act aims to award grants to organizations for local health care quality reforms, funding beneficial practices, expanding information technology, developing reimbursement practices, lowering delivery costs, and encouraging experimentation in different regions. The Act aims to encourage experimentation in different regions of the United States and reward cooperation among local entities engaged in reforming the health care system. The Quality Reform Grant Initiative is established under Section 3 of the Act to promote collaboration among local entities in reforming the healthcare system. The Quality Reform Grant Initiative, established under Section 3 of the Act, awards grants to eligible State, local, and regional entities to implement quality reform plans for healthcare improvement. Eligible entities focus on quality improvement, health information technology, cost-effective prevention, and reimbursement system restructuring. Additionally, a Quality Reform Committee is to be established within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Quality Reform Committee, established within 180 days of the Act's enactment, shall consist of at least 7 members appointed by various healthcare authorities. The Committee's general duties include approving grant applications, facilitating communication among entities, and evaluating best practices for grant activities. Grantees under this section are encouraged to collaborate, share research, recognize achievements publicly, overcome obstacles, integrate with the private sector, and report on market failures. Members assist with coordinating information technology infrastructure and serve as facilitators for local programs. Members serve for a term determined by the appointing authority and select a Chairperson from among themselves. The Committee shall hold an annual public meeting for grantees to report progress and exchange information with each other and the Committee. The Committee may obtain information from Federal departments or agencies as needed and may enter into contracts. The Quality Reform Committee, established within 180 days of the Act's enactment, consists of at least 7 members appointed by healthcare authorities. Members select a Chairperson from among themselves. The Committee may enter into contracts with qualified independent organizations to obtain necessary information. They may also use postal services and address personnel matters such as compensation for non-government members. The Quality Reform Committee members shall be compensated at a rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. Officers or employees of the US serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed at authorized rates. The Quality Reform Committee members are compensated at level IV of the Executive Schedule for their duty days. The Chairperson can appoint staff without following civil service laws. Federal employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. Temporary and intermittent services are also allowed. The Chairperson of the Committee may procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for level V of the Executive Schedule. $2,000,000 are authorized to be appropriated for fiscal year 2008 and each subsequent fiscal year for this purpose. To be eligible for a grant, an entity must submit a Quality Reform Plan as part of the application. The Committee requires a plan to improve quality of care in grant applications, including local healthcare community involvement, cost-saving strategies, electronic health record implementation, and evidence-based investment in prevention and detection of illness. The grant program aims to improve quality of care by involving local healthcare communities, implementing cost-saving strategies, electronic health records, and investing in prevention and detection of illness. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 2 years and can be renewed. States with grantees receive expedited consideration for waivers from Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to achieve grant objectives. The amount of a grant awarded to an entity shall be determined based upon the recommendations of the Committee, subject to appropriations, but is intended to be an unrestricted grant to eligible entities with qualifying plans. An entity that is awarded a grant shall submit an annual report to the Committee containing a description of the results of activities carried out under the project. The Committee shall prepare and submit a report to Congress on the grants awarded under this section within a 5-year period. The Act requires a report on grant progress to be submitted to Congress. The Senate recommends holding hearings on the report within 45 days. $100,000,000 is authorized for the Act over a 10-year period starting in 2008.
